review.title: DNA-inspired online behavioral modeling and its application to spambot detection
review.abstract: We propose a strikingly novel, simple, and effective approach to model online user behavior: we extract and analyze digital DNA sequences from user online actions and we use Twitter as a benchmark to test our proposal. We obtain an incisive and compact DNA-inspired characterization of user actions. Then, we apply standard DNA analysis techniques to discriminate between genuine and spambot accounts on Twitter. An experimental campaign supports our proposal, showing its effectiveness and viability. To the best of our knowledge, we are the first ones to identify and adapt DNA-inspired techniques to online user behavioral modeling. While Twitter spambot detection is a specific use case on a specific social media, our proposed methodology is platform and technology agnostic, hence paving the way for diverse behavioral characterization tasks.

sections.heading: A. Biological DNA
sections.text: The human genome is the complete set of genetic information about man (Homo sapiens), encoded as nucleic acid (DNA) sequences. DNA sequences are sequences of characters (i.e. strings) that indicate the sequence of nucleotides within DNA molecules. Possible signs are A, C, G, and T, which represent the four nucleotide bases of a DNA strand: adenine, cytosine, guanine, and thymine. Biological DNA stores the information-conducting functions and characteristics of a living organism. DNA sequences are analyzed using bioinformatics techniques. Sequence matching and decoding are among the best-known methods of analysis to find similarities and repetitions of sequences. By analyzing common sub-sequences, it is possible to predict specific characteristics of the individual and reveal relationships between different individuals.

sections.heading: B. Digital DNA as a proxy of user online behavior
sections.text: Inspired by biological DNA, interactions are characterized by the way in which users interact, in which they represent the sequence of a user's online actions. Each individual action (e.g. the publication of new content that follows a user) can be encrypted with a different character, similar to the DNA sequences in which users "characters have behaved in their own way. In accordance with this paradigm, online user actions are the basis of their digital communication, the different types of user behavior can be observed on the Internet [6] and digital DNA is a flexible and compact way to model such behaviors. Its flexibility lies in the ability to identify the behavior of people.

sections.heading: A. Mining groups of digital DNA sequences
sections.text: The basic assumption of digital DNA fingerprinting technique is to view behaviors as sequences of action and to characterize and recognize social spambots by grouping similar sequences. Therefore, our approach falls into the broad field of sequential data mining, but it presents differences to the tasks that are usually performed when working with sequential data. Sequences are ordered lists of symbols from an alphabet B, namely s = {s1, s2,.. sn}, with si-B and are used in information retrieval, part-of-speech tagging, genomics, time series analysis - to name a few. Tasks that are frequently performed with such sequences are those of sequential supervised learning, sequence classification of sequences. sections.heading: IV. DIGITAL DNA FINGERPRINTING FOR SPAMBOT DETECTION

sections.heading: A. Characterizing spambot behavior
sections.text: The digital DNA fingerprinting process has four main steps: (i) collecting behavioral data, each representing a string; (ii) extracting DNA sequences; (iii) comparing DNA sequences; (iv) evaluating DNA accounts. In order to perform a rigorous evaluation of our detection technology, we have created records of verified spambots and real Twitter accounts. All accounts in our datasets have undergone manual verification, in particular 50.05% (991 accounts) of Bot1 accounts and 89.29% (464 accounts) of Bot2 accounts have been certified as spambots. Then, we have built a dataset of human accounts by contacting users randomly and asking them simple questions in natural language. All 3,474 accounts that have been certified as human. For all 4,929 accounts in our datasets, we have collected behavioral data by performing the second step of their digital extraction.

sections.heading: B. Uncovering novel Twitter spambots
sections.text: This, in turn, can cause us to suspect a high level of automation for these accounts that behave in a similar way. Building on the promising results we have obtained with the tweet type DNA, we are using the characteristics of LCS curves below to effectively detect groups of Twitter spambots. Our detection techniques can be applied to a group of accounts that are not tagged to verify that there are accounts with suspiciously similar behavior. In a group of mixed accounts and genuine accounts, almost only bot accounts will have long DNA substrings in common. Thus, by identifying the group of accounts that share a long LCS, we can get a number of suspicious accounts.

sections.heading: V. CONCLUSION
sections.text: The novelty of our proposal is based on modeling behaviors in a DNA-inspired way. Therefore, we allow analysts to use a range of powerful tools - developed over decades for DNA analysis - to validate their working hypotheses on online user behavior. To demonstrate the feasibility of our proposal, we have conducted an extensive experimental campaign using Twitter as a benchmark and targeted spambot detection, and the results show that our proposal outperforms the best algorithms commonly used for this task. Finally, we argue that the proposed method could also be used in other contexts, paving the way for further research.
